artefact.overview: You usually stop paying child maintenance when the child reaches 16 - unless they're in full-time non-advanced education
artefact.body:
Child maintenance payments stop when the child reaches 16, or 19 if they’re in full-time education not higher than A-level equivalent.

If the child is 16 or over and gets Income Support, the Child Support Agency (CSA) no longer sees them as a child, so payments will stop.

If the paying parent owes child maintenance (‘arrears’), they’re still liable for the outstanding payments even after child maintenance has stopped.

If the paying parent goes to prison, they don’t have to pay child maintenance while they’re serving their sentence.

The ‘paying parent’ is the parent the child doesn’t live with. The parent or carer they live with is called the ‘receiving parent’.
